``License to Kill'' (CBS-Fox Video. VHS-Beta, $89.98. Rated PG-13)
Bond _ James Bond _ is a grim figure in ``Licence to Kill,'' in which the secret agent takes on a murderous Latin drug lord in Florida and Latin America. While earlier 007 films offered a sly, roguish charmer given to jaunty double entrendres, ``Licence to Kill'' serves up a moody, humorless Bond. Which is to say, no Bond at all. Bond, played by Timothy Dalton in his second 007 film, is upstaged this time by the gadgetry and special effects. Worse, not even the villain lives up to the usual standards. While previous villains were often megalomaniacs who wanted nothing less than the entire world, Sanchez _ played with reptilian charm by pockmarked Robert Davi _ is a bad guy of almost real-life proportions. He's not much worse than some of the drug lords making headlines these days. In place of Bond, ``Licence to Kill'' offers lots of violence, including a few gruesomely creative ways to die, and the usual fiendish weapons, as unveiled by gadget scientist Q. Davi is so believable that his character comes off as conventional. Talisa Soto is perfectly wooden as Sanchez's _ and later Bond's _ love interest, and Carey Lowell plays an agent whose most alluring quality is the way she keeps her gun in a thigh garter. But without a compelling Bond, ``License to Kill'' rarely rises above the level of a good episode of ``Miami Vice.''

``Road House'' (MGM-UA Home Video. VHS-Beta, $89.95. Rated R)
The Double Deuce is a down and dirty bar where the low-rent patrons mix it up at the slightest provocation, a toilet of a place so mean that someone hits a blind guitarist in the face with a bottle. Then comes Dalton (Patrick Swayze). Dalton _ a bouncer with fists of steel, Zen-like calm and a philosophy degree from New York University _ weeds out the undesirables among his bouncers, schools them in self-restraint and has the place looking like a yuppie nightspot in no time. But in doing so he runs afoul of Brad Wesley, a high-class thug who bleeds local merchants for protection money and at one point flips a coin to decide who will live and who will die. This is a violent tale as simple-minded as a comic book, and this bouncer-with-a-brain stuff is a little much. But ``Road House'' is packed with action and rollicks along to a rip-roaring ending. Swayze (``Dirty Dancing'') gets the job done as a sort of next-generation, shirtless Clint Eastwood, playing a squinty-eyed loner from out of town who takes on the local bully. Ben Gazzara is a stylishly evil Wesley. ``Road House.'' See it in the safety of your own home.
